text: (upbeat music)
- Dropbox was facing a capacity crunch
with our on-premise metadata systems.
We're very actively trying to make

our technical infrastructure
as flexible as possible.

We're doing this by first
adopting open standards,

like Kubernetes, Terraform,
things like that,

to enable us to actually
move workloads around,
whether it's on premise or in the cloud.
We looked to AWS to help us solve that

and do it in a way that
scales to our needs
as well as to our cost requirements.
We were able to stand up our Alki service,

which is essentially a cold
metadata service in AWS,
leveraging DynamoDB, Amazon S3,
really get it up and going really fast.

AWS gives us the
flexibility, the services,
and really provides us the ability to have
cost effective solutions in the cloud

that'll help us move toward
a hybrid cloud model.

We'll be able to very
quickly stand up new services

using the cloud where we wouldn't
have been able to on-prem.
